text:
What should you do if you
have to stop while you're
going through a congested
tunnel?

options.A: Pull up very close to the vehicle in front to save space
options.B: Ignore any message signs, as they're never up to date
options.C: Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front
options.D: Make a U-turn and find another route

explanation: Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. Maintain proper spacing even in tunnels.

text:
You arrive at the scene of a crash where someone is bleeding heavily from a 
wound in their arm. Nothing is embedded in the wound. What could you do to help?

options.B: Walk them around and keep them talking
options.C: Apply pressure over the wound
options.D: Get them a drink

explanation: Switch on your hazard warning lights. Warn other drivers of the obstruction or hazard.

text:
You're at an incident.
What could you do to help
an unconscious casualty?

options.B: Splash their face with cool water
options.C: Move them to somewhere more comfortable
options.D: Check that they're breathing normally

explanation: Drive on carefully. Don't stop on motorways unless it's an emergency.

text:
A casualty isn't breathing normally and needs CPR. At what rate should you press down and release on the 
centre of their chest?

options.B: 240 times per minute
options.C: 60 times per minute
options.D: 120 times per minute

explanation: Stop and call the emergency services. Report accidents involving injury immediately.

text: Following a collision, a person has been injured. What would be a warning sign for shock?

options.B: Warm dry skin
options.C: Slow pulse
options.D: Rapid shallow breathing

explanation: Use an emergency telephone. These directly connect to emergency services and show your location.

text:
An injured person has 
been placed in the recovery position. They're 
unconscious but breathing normally. What else should be done?

options.B: Press firmly between their shoulders
options.C: Give them a hot sweet drink
options.D: Place their arms by their side

explanation: Send someone to call for help. Get professional medical help immediately for injuries.

text:
An injured motorcyclist is lying unconscious in the 
road. The traffic has stopped and there's no further 
danger. What could you do to help?

options.B: Seek medical assistance
options.C: Move the person off the road
options.D: Remove their safety helmet

explanation: Switch off the fuel supply. This reduces fire risk in vehicle accidents.

text:
What should you do if you
see a large box fall from a
lorry onto the motorway?

options.A: Go to the next emergency telephone and report the hazard
options.B: Catch up with the lorry and try to get the driver's attention
options.C: Stop close to the box until the police arrive
options.D: Pull over to the hard shoulder, then remove the box

explanation: Don't remove their helmet. Removing helmets can cause further spinal injury.

text:
You're going through a
long tunnel. What will warn
you of congestion or an
incident ahead?

options.B: Areas with hatch markings
options.C: Other drivers flashing their lights
options.D: Variable message signs

explanation: Get them out of the vehicle. Fire risk means evacuating casualties if safe to do so.

text:
An adult casualty isn't 
breathing. To maintain 
circulation, CPR should be given. What's the correct 
depth to press down on their chest?

options.B: 1 to 2 centimetres
options.C: 5 to 6 centimetres
options.D: 15 to 20 centimetres

explanation: Loosen any tight clothing. This helps injured people breathe more easily.

text:
You're the first person to arrive at an incident where people are badly injured.
You’ve switched on your hazard warning lights and checked all engines are 
stopped. What else should you do?

options.A: Make sure that an ambulance has been called
options.B: Move the people who are injured clear of their vehicles
options.C: Try and get people who are injured to drink something
options.D: Stop other cars and ask the drivers for help

explanation: Call the emergency services immediately. Professional medical help is crucial for serious injuries.

text:
You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle crash. The 
rider is injured. When 
should their helmet be 
removed?

options.B: Only when it's essential
options.C: Always straight away
options.D: Only when the motorcyclist asks

explanation: Keep them warm and comfortable. Treat for shock by keeping casualty warm.

text:
You arrive at an incident. There's no danger from fire or further collisions and the emergency services have 
been called. What's your 
first priority when attending to an unconscious 
motorcyclist?

options.B: Check whether they have any bruising
options.C: Check whether they're breathing normally
options.D: Check whether they have any broken bones

explanation: Clear the airway and check breathing. ABC - Airway, Breathing, Circulation.

text:
At an incident, someone
is unconscious and you
want to help. What would be
the first thing to check?

options.B: Whether their vehicle is insured
options.C: Whether their airway is open
options.D: Whether they have any allergies

explanation: Phone for medical assistance. Get professional help for all injury accidents.

text:
What could you do to
help injured people at an
incident?

options.B: Keep them warm and comfortable
options.C: Give them something to eat
options.D: Keep them on the move by walking them around

explanation: Place them in the recovery position. This keeps airways clear for unconscious breathing casualties.

text:
There's been a collision.
How can you help a driver
who's suffering from shock?

options.B: Give them a drink
options.C: Reassure them confidently
options.D: Ask who caused the incident

explanation: Stop, but only if it's safe to do so. Assess safety before stopping at any incident.

text:
You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle crash. No 
other vehicle is involved. 
The rider is unconscious 
and lying in the middle of 
the road. What's the first 
thing you should do at the scene?

options.B: Warn other traffic
options.C: Give the rider reassurance
options.D: Move the rider out of the road

explanation: Use an emergency telephone. These connect directly to highways agencies.

text:
At an incident, how
could you help a small child
who isn't breathing?

options.A: Find their parents and explain what's happening
options.B: Talk to them confidently until an ambulance arrives
options.C: Put them in the recovery position and slap their back
options.D: Open their airway and begin CPR

explanation: Switch off the vehicle's engine. Reduce fire risk at accident scenes.

text:
At an incident, a casualty
isn't breathing. What should
you do while helping them to
start breathing again?

options.B: Put their arms across their chest
options.C: Roll them onto their side
options.D: Shake them firmly

explanation: Check the casualty's breathing. Airway and breathing are first priorities.

text:
At an incident, someone
is suffering from severe
burns. How could you help
them?

options.B: Douse the burns with clean, cool water
options.C: Remove anything sticking to the burns
options.D: Apply lotions to the injury

explanation: Warn other traffic. Prevent further accidents by warning approaching vehicles.

text:
You arrive at an incident. A pedestrian is bleeding 
heavily from a leg wound. The leg isn't broken and 
there's nothing in the 
wound. How could you 
help?

options.B: Apply firm pressure over the wound
options.C: Keep the casualty's legs flat on the ground
options.D: Dab the wound to stop the bleeding

explanation: Give mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. If someone isn't breathing, start rescue breaths.

text:
At an incident, a casualty
is unconscious but
breathing. When should you
move them?

options.A: When an ambulance is on its way
options.B: When bystanders tell you to move them
options.C: When there's a risk of further danger
options.D: When bystanders offer to help you

explanation: Apply firm pressure to the wound. Direct pressure helps control bleeding.

text:
At an incident, it's
important to look after any
casualties. What should you
do with them when the area
is safe?

options.B: Move them away from the vehicles
options.C: Ask them how it happened
options.D: Give them something to eat

explanation: Stop and give assistance. It's your legal and moral duty to stop and help.

text:
After a collision, 
someone is unconscious in their vehicle. When should you call the emergency 
services?

options.B: Only as a last resort
options.C: As soon as possible
options.D: After you've woken them up

explanation: Do nothing until medical help arrives. Don't give food, drink, or move casualties unnecessarily.

text:
A collision has just 
happened. An injured 
person is lying in a busy road. What’s the first thing you should do?

options.B: Make sure the injured person is kept warm
options.C: Place them in the recovery position
options.D: Warn other traffic

explanation: Use an emergency telephone. These provide direct connection to emergency services.

text:
At an incident, how
could you help a casualty
who has stopped breathing?

options.B: Try to give them something to drink
options.C: Raise their legs to help with circulation
options.D: Keep their head tilted forwards as far as possible

explanation: Keep casualties warm. Shock treatment includes maintaining body temperature.

text:
You’re at the scene of an incident. How could you 
help someone who's 
suffering from shock?

options.B: Give them a warm drink
options.C: Offer them some food
options.D: Offer them a cigarette

explanation: Call for medical help. Head injuries always require professional medical assessment.

text:
There's been a collision.
A motorcyclist is lying 
injured and unconscious.
Why should you only 
remove their helmet if it’s essential?

options.A: Removing it could let them get cold
options.B: Removing it could make any injuries worse
options.C: You could scratch the helmet as you remove it
options.D: They might not want you to remove it

explanation: Cover the burn with a clean cloth. Protect burns from infection with clean covering.

text:
You're on a motorway.
When can you use hazard
warning lights?

options.A: When a vehicle is following too closely
options.B: When you're being towed by another vehicle
options.C: When you're using the hard shoulder as a running lane
options.D: When you slow down quickly because of danger ahead

explanation: Stop at the scene. You must stop if you're involved in any accident.

text:
You've broken down on a two-way road. You have a 
warning triangle. At least 
how far from your vehicle 
should you place the 
warning triangle?

options.B: 5 metres (16 feet)
options.C: 25 metres (82 feet)
options.D: 45 metres (147 feet)

explanation: Clear the airway. First check and clear the airway for breathing casualties.

text:
Your car breaks down on
a level crossing. What's the
first thing you should do?

options.A: Stay in your car until you're told to move
options.B: Tell drivers behind what's happened
options.C: Leave your vehicle and get everyone clear
options.D: Walk down the track and signal the next train

explanation: Move them to fresh air. Carbon monoxide poisoning requires fresh air immediately.

text:
What should you do if a
tyre bursts while you’re
driving?

options.B: Pull on the parking brake
options.C: Continue on at a normal speed
options.D: Pull up slowly at the side of the road

explanation: Call the emergency services. Always report injury accidents to police.

text:
What should you do if
your vehicle has a puncture
on a motorway?

options.A: Pull up on the hard shoulder or in an emergency refuge area and call for assistance
options.B: Switch on your hazard warning lights. Stop in your lane
options.C: Drive slowly to the next service area to get assistance
options.D: Pull up on the hard shoulder or in an emergency refuge area. Change the wheel as quickly as possible

explanation: Apply pressure to the wound. Control bleeding with direct pressure.

text:
Your vehicle has stalled in the middle of a level 
crossing. What should you do if the warning bells start to ring while you're trying to restart the engine?

options.A: Get out of the car and clear of the crossing
options.B: Carry on trying to restart the engine
options.C: Push the vehicle clear of the crossing
options.D: Run down the track to warn the signal operator

explanation: Check they can breathe. Ensure airways are clear and casualty is breathing.

text:
What should you do
before driving into a tunnel?

options.B: Take off your sunglasses
options.C: Close your sunroof
options.D: Switch on your windscreen wipers

explanation: Report it to the police. Non-injury accidents must be reported if details aren't exchanged.

text:
Which lights should you
use when you're driving in a
tunnel?

options.B: Rear fog lights
options.C: Sidelights
options.D: Dipped headlights

explanation: Keep them warm. Maintaining body temperature helps prevent or treat shock.

text:
What should you do to
reduce the risk of your
vehicle catching fire?

options.A: Check out any strong smell of fuel
options.B: Keep water levels above maximum
options.C: Use fuel additives
options.D: Avoid driving with a full tank of fuel

explanation: Switch off the fuel supply. Reduces fire risk at accident scenes.

text:
You're driving on the 
motorway. What should you do if luggage falls from your vehicle?

options.A: Stop on the motorway and switch on hazard warning lights while you pick it up
options.B: Stop at the next emergency telephone and report the incident
options.C: Walk back up the motorway to pick it up
options.D: Pull up on the hard shoulder and wave traffic down

explanation: Use the emergency telephone. Direct connection to emergency services with location.

text:
What should you do if an
instrument panel warning
light comes on while you're
driving?

options.A: Hope that it's just a temporary electrical fault
options.B: Deal with the problem when there's more time
options.C: Continue if the engine sounds all right
options.D: Check out the problem quickly and safely

explanation: Place them in the recovery position. Maintains open airway for unconscious breathing casualties.

text:
What should you do if
your vehicle breaks down in
a tunnel?

options.A: Stand in front of your vehicle to warn oncoming drivers
options.B: Stand in the lane behind your vehicle to warn others
options.C: Switch on hazard warning lights, then go and call for help
options.D: Stay in your vehicle and wait for the police

explanation: Approach with care. Always assess hazards before entering accident scenes.

text:
What should you do if
your vehicle catches fire
while you're driving through
a tunnel?

options.A: Park it away from the carriageway
options.B: Leave it where it is, with the engine running
options.C: Pull up, then walk to an emergency telephone
options.D: Drive it out of the tunnel if it's safe to do so

explanation: Keep them still. Don't move casualties unless there's immediate danger.

text:
What should you do first
if your vehicle has broken
down on an automatic
railway level crossing?

options.A: Walk along the track to give warning to any approaching trains
options.B: Try to push the vehicle clear of the crossing as soon as possible
options.C: Get everyone out of the vehicle and clear of the crossing
options.D: Telephone your vehicle recovery service to move it

explanation: Move them away from the vehicle. Fire risk means evacuating casualties when safe.

text:
What's the first thing you
must do if you have a
collision while you're driving
your car?

options.B: Stop only if someone waves at you
options.C: Call the emergency services
options.D: Stop at the scene of the incident

explanation: Check for danger first. Scene safety is the first priority before helping.

text:
What information should
you share if you’re involved
in a collision that causes
damage to another vehicle?

options.A: Your name, address and vehicle registration number
options.B: Your national insurance number
options.C: Your internet service provider
options.D: Your occupation and reason for your journey

explanation: Your name, address and vehicle registration number. These are the legally required details to exchange after a collision.

text:
You lose control of your
car and damage a garden
wall. What must you do if the
property owner isn't
available?

options.A: Report the incident to your insurance company when you get home
options.B: Go back to tell the house owner the next day
options.C: Report the incident to the police within 24 hours
options.D: Find someone in the area to tell them about it immediately

explanation: Report the incident to the police within 24 hours. You must report damage to property if the owner isn't present.
